title: Juan-Philip Smith
text:
Juan-Philip Smith (born 30 March 1994) is a South African professional <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> player who plays for the <a href="Seattle%20Seawolves">Seattle Seawolves</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Rugby">Major League Rugby</a> (MLR) in the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>. His regular position is scrum-half, but he has played as a fly-half on occasion.
Career.
Border (2010–11).
At high school level, Smith earned provincial selection to represent Border. He played for them at the 2010 Under-16 Grant Khomo Week in <a href="Upington">Upington</a> and the 2011 Under-18 <a href="Craven%20Week">Craven Week</a> – South Africa's premier high school competition – in <a href="Kimberley%2C%20Northern%20Cape">Kimberley</a>. He was also eligible to play at the 2012 Craven Week, but was not picked as he had agreed to join the <a href="Pretoria">Pretoria</a>-based and fell foul of a newly adopted Border Rugby Football Union policy of not picking players for their Craven Week squad that already signed contracts with other unions.
Blue Bulls and South Africa Under-20 (2013–15).
He started in twelve matches for the side in the <a href="2013%20Under-19%20Provincial%20Championship">2013 Under-19 Provincial Championship</a>, including three matches as a fly-half. He scored a total of 31 points during the season, including 14 points in their match against , which also saw Smith score his only try of the competition. The Blue Bulls won all twelve of their matches during the regular season to finish top of the log and to quality for the title play-offs. Smith started in their 37–21 victory over the s in the semi-final and in the final, where he helped his side become champions by beating <a href="Gauteng">Gauteng</a> rivals 35–23.
In 2014, he was included in the ' squad for the <a href="2014%20Vodacom%20Cup">2014 Vodacom Cup</a> competition. However, he failed to appear in this competition as he was included in the <a href="South%20Africa%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">South Africa Under-20</a> squad that participated at the <a href="2014%20IRB%20Junior%20World%20Championship">IRB Junior World Championship</a> held in <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>. He played off the bench in their first match as South Africa beat <a href="Scotland%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">Scotland</a> 61–5, and started their other two matches in the pool stage, a 33–24 win over hosts <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand</a> and a 21–8 win over <a href="Samoa%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">Samoa</a> to finish top of their pool. He started their semi-final match as they again met <a href="New%20Zealand%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">New Zealand</a> in the semi-finals and beat them, this time by a 32–25 scoreline, to qualify to their second final. He remained the starting scrum-half for the final, but was on the losing side as <a href="England%20national%20under-20%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> won the match 21–20 to consign South Africa to the runner-up spot.
Smith returned to domestic action with the s in the <a href="2014%20Under-21%20Provincial%20Championship">2014 Under-21 Provincial Championship</a>. He started six of their matches in the competition and appeared as a replacement in four more. He also scored one of the Blue Bulls' 21 tries in their 143–0 victory over on the opening day of the season and eventually helped them to finish the regular season in second position. He started their 23–19 victory over the s in the semi-final, but did not feature in the final, where the Blue Bulls beat 20–10 to be crowned champions.
He was again named in the ' squad for the <a href="2015%20Vodacom%20Cup">2015 Vodacom Cup</a>. After being an unused replacement in their 20–18 victory over eventual champions the , he made his domestic first class debut in their next match, a 44–0 victory over <a href="Namibia">Namibia</a>n side in <a href="Windhoek">Windhoek</a>. After his first appearance on domestic soil against the a week later, he made his first start in their quarter final match against a , helping the Blue Bulls to a 44–21 victory. He also started in their semi-final match against , but ended on the losing side as the team from <a href="Cape%20Town">Cape Town</a> ran out 10–6 winners.
He featured in nine of the s' matches in the <a href="2015%20Under-21%20Provincial%20Championship%20Group%20A">2015 Under-21 Provincial Championship</a>. He scored a try in their 41–31 victory over the , but experience a poor season overall as the defending champions finished in fifth spot on the log to fail to qualify for the play-offs.
Cheetahs (2016–).
Smith was named in the training squad of <a href="Bloemfontein">Bloemfontein</a>-based <a href="Super%20Rugby">Super Rugby</a> franchise the for the <a href="2016%20Super%20Rugby%20season">2016 Super Rugby season</a>.
